name: Olympus Mons
details: Largest volcano and second-highest known mountain in the Solar System. It is over 21.9 km (13.6 mi or 72,000 ft) high, as measured by the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter, and is about two and a half times Mount Everest's height above sea level. Olympus Mons is the youngest of the large volcanoes on Mars, having formed during Mars's Hesperian Period with eruptions continuing well into the Amazonian.  Olympus Mons stands 21 km (13 mi) above the Mars global datum.

name: Valles Marineris
details: Largest canyon in the Solar System also one of the largest canyons of the solar system. It is 4 miles deep and stretches thousands of miles long. Valles Marineris is located along the equator of Mars, on the east side of the Tharsis Bulge, and stretches for nearly a quarter of the planet's circumference.

name: Hellas Planitia
details: Largest impact crater on Mars. Hellas is the third- or fourth-largest known impact crater in the Solar System. The basin floor is about 7,152 m (23,465 ft) deep, 3,000 m (9,800 ft) deeper than the Moon's South Pole-Aitken basin, and extends about 2,300 km (1,400 mi) east to west.

name: Argyre Planitia
details: Second largest impact crater on Mars. Its name comes from a map produced by Giovanni Schiaparelli in 1877; it refers to Argyre, a mythical island of silver in Greek mythology. The basin is approximately 1,800 km (1,100 mi) wide and drops 5.2 km (17,000 ft) below the surrounding plains; it is the second deepest impact basin on Mars after Hellas.

name: Isidis Planitia
details: Isidis Planitia is a plain located within a giant impact basin on Mars, located partly in the Syrtis Major quadrangle and partly in the Amenthes quadrangle. At approximately 1,500 km (930 mi) in diameter, it is the third-largest obvious impact structure on the planet, after the Hellas and Argyre basins.

name: Ascraeus Mons
details: Second-highest volcano on Mars. In 1971. The volcano was originally called North Spot because it was the northernmost of only four spots visible on the surface due to a global dust storm that was then enshrouding the planet. As the dust cleared, the spots were revealed to be extremely tall volcanoes whose summits had projected above the dust-laden, lower atmosphere.

name: Pavonis Mons
details: Third-highest volcano on Mars. It is the middle member of a chain of three volcanic mountains collectively known as the Tharsis Montes. Pavonis Mons is the smallest of the Tharsis Montes volcanoes, measuring about 375 km across and standing 14 km above Mars' mean surface level. As a shield volcano, Pavonis Mons has an extremely low profile with flank slopes that average only 4°.

name: Arsia Mons
details: Fourth-highest volcano on Mars.  Its name comes from a corresponding albedo feature on a map by Giovanni Schiaparelli, which he named in turn after the legendary Roman forest of Arsia Silva. Historically, it was known as Nodus Gordii ("Gordian knot") before being renamed.

name: Acidalia Planitia
details: Acidalia Planitia is a plain on Mars, between the Tharsis volcanic province and Arabia Terra to the north of Valles Marineris. It is the large lowland plain on Mars.  The plain contains the famous Cydonia region at the contact with the heavily cratered highland terrain.

name: Gale Crater
details: Home to the Curiosity rover. It is probably a dry lake. It is 154 km (96 mi) in diameter and estimated to be about 3.5 to 3.8 billion years old. Mount Sharp is a mountain in the center of Gale and rises 5.5 km (18,000 ft) high. The NASA Mars rover Curiosity, of the Mars Science Laboratory (MSL) mission, landed in "Yellowknife" Quad 51 of Aeolis Palus in Gale at 05:32 UTC August 6, 2012.

name: Jezero Crater
details: Jezero Crater's history reveals multiple cycles of water presence. Over 3.5 billion years ago, rivers formed a lake, carrying clay minerals. This offers potential clues about past Martian life. It is a crater on Mars in the Syrtis Major quadrangle, about 45.0 km (28.0 mi) in diameter. Home to the Perseverance rover. Thought to have once been flooded with water, the crater contains a fan-delta deposit rich in clays. In some Slavic languages, the word jezero means 'lake'. In November 2018, it was announced that Jezero had been chosen as the landing site for the rover Perseverance as part of NASA's Mars 2020 mission.

name: Elysium Mons
details: Largest volcano in the northern hemisphere of Mars. It stands about 12.6 km (41,000 ft) above its base, and about 14.1 km (46,000 ft) above the Martian datum, making it the third tallest Martian mountain in terms of relief and the fourth highest in elevation. Its diameter is about 240 km (150 mi), with a summit caldera about 14 km (8.7 mi) across.

name: Syrtis Major
details: Syrtis Major Planum is a "dark spot" (an albedo feature) located in the boundary between the northern lowlands and southern highlands of Mars just west of the impact basin Isidis in the Syrtis Major quadrangle.It is the second-largest volcano in the southern hemisphere of Mars with a well-defined summit caldera.

name: Olympia Undae
details: Olympia Undae consists of a broad "sand sea" or erg that partly rings the north polar plateau (Planum Boreum) from about 120° to 240°E longitude and 78° to 83°N latitude. Stretching about 1,100 km (680 mi) across and covering an area of 470,000 km2. is the largest continuous dune field on Mars.

name: Amazonis Planitia
details: Largest plain on Mars. Amazonis Planitia is one of the smoothest plains on Mars. It is located between the Tharsis and Elysium volcanic provinces, to the west of Olympus Mons. The plain's topography exhibits extremely smooth features at several different lengths of scale.

name: Tharsis
details: The region is home to the largest volcanoes in the Solar System, including the three enormous shield volcanoes Arsia Mons, Pavonis Mons, and Ascraeus Mons, which are collectively known as the Tharsis Montes. It is called largest highland region on Mars. The tallest volcano on the planet, Olympus Mons, is often associated with the Tharsis region but is actually located off the western edge of the plateau. Water clouds can be seen over Tharsis

name: Arabia Terra
details: Largest highland region in the northern hemisphere of Mars. It is densely cratered and heavily eroded. This battered topography indicates great age, and Arabia Terra is presumed to be one of the oldest terrains on the planet. It covers as much as 4,500 km (2,800 mi) at its longest extent

name: Noachis Terra
details: Largest highland region in the southern hemisphere of Mars. It is in the Noachis quadrangle.

name: Borealis Basin
details: Largest and oldest impact basin on Mars, encompassing much of the northern lowlands. Some scientists have postulated that the basin formed during the impact of a single, large body roughly 2% of the mass of Mars, having a diameter of about 1,900 km (1,200 miles) early in the history of Mars, around 4.5 billion years ago. The basin is one of the flattest areas in the Solar System, and has an elliptical shape.

name: Aonia Terra
location: Southern hemisphere of the planet Mars
details: It is named after a classical albedo feature Aonia, that was named after the ancient Greek region Aonia. Aonia Terra is an upland area notable for massive cratering including the large Lowell Crater, parts of the region features small craters, in the plain areas, Thaumasia Fossae and parts of the southern area.

name: Terra Cimmeria
details: Terra Cimmeria, forms a part of Mars' heavily cratered southern highlands. It's known as the landing site for the Spirit rover and is linked to an ancient Thracian seafaring people, with its name inspired by a land shrouded in clouds and mist.

name: Margaritifer Terra
details: Margaritifer Terra, located near Mars' equator, is a heavily cratered region revealing 'chaos terrain,' outflow channels, and alluvial plains that suggest massive flooding. The region also hosts Ares Vallis, known for its flood and flow patterns and as a historic landing site. Notably, the Holden and Eberswalde craters were likely ancient lakes due to their delta and mineral content. The Uzboi-Landon-Morava water flow paths are found here, carved by rapid groundwater outflows. Margaritifer Terra's history suggests a thicker atmosphere in Mars' past.

name: North Polar Basin
details: Encompassing 40% of the planet, the North Polar Basin, also known as the Borealis Basin, is a significant feature in the Martian northern hemisphere. It is believed to have formed through a large impact event roughly 4.5 billion years ago, possibly caused by a single body about 2% the mass of Mars. The basin's elliptical shape and remarkably flat terrain make it a distinctive feature in the Solar System.

name: Promethei Terra
location: Southern hemisphere of Mars, east of the Hellas basin
details: Promethei Terra, situated in the southern hemisphere of Mars, covers 3300 km at its widest extent. It's characterized by its heavily cratered highland terrain and is located to the east of the vast Hellas basin. Named after the Greek god Prometheus, it lies mostly within the Hellas quadrangle. Notably, the region features lobate debris aprons (LDAs) which consist of material surrounding cliffs.

name: Terra Sabaea
details: Terra Sabaea is a vast region on Mars, spanning 4,700 kilometers at its widest extent. It was named after a classic albedo feature on the planet and is located within multiple quadrangles. Notably, some landscapes in Terra Sabaea resemble glaciers on Earth, exhibiting features resembling moraines left by retreating ice. These glacier-like forms are known as viscous flow features (VFF) and suggest dynamic processes in the past.

name: Terra Sirenum
details: Terra Sirenum, situated in Mars' southern hemisphere, spans 3900 km at its broadest extent. Notably known for extensive cratering, including the prominent Newton Crater, this upland area is found within the Phaethontis and Memnonia quadrangles. An intriguing feature is a former low area that likely contained a lake, which later drained through Ma'adim Vallis. The region's name draws from the Sirens of mythology, capturing the connection between Mars' landscape and stories of the past.

name: Tempe Terra
details: Tempe Terra, situated in Mars' northern hemisphere, is a heavily cratered highland region notable for its distinctive features. Positioned at the northeastern edge of the Tharsis volcanic province, it showcases significant crustal fracturing, deformation, and various volcanic structures. Named after the Vale of Tempe, a picturesque valley celebrated by ancient Greeks, Tempe Terra is a vast region extending from about 30° to 54°N and from 265° to 310°E, covering approximately 2.1 million km2. This highland area is bordered by Chryse and Acidalia Planitiae to the east, low-lying plains to the north, and the extensive Kasei Valles outflow channel system to the south.

name: Tyrrhena Terra
details: Tyrrhena Terra, situated south of the Martian equator and northeast of the Hellas basin, covers an expanse of 2300 km at its widest point. This region, located in the Mare Tyrrhenum quadrangle, is characterized by heavily cratered highlands and rugged terrain, representing the typical southern Martian terrae. Notably, Tyrrhena Terra features the ancient Tyrrhena Patera volcano and significant formations like Herschel crater, Licus Vallis, and Ausonia Montes. The landscape also exhibits channels and dunes, as captured in images.

name: Xanthe Terra
details: Xanthe Terra, positioned near Mars' equator, spans an area of approximately 1867.65 km in diameter. The region's name, meaning 'golden-yellow land,' is fitting for its distinctive landscape. Found within the Lunae Palus, Coprates, Margaritifer Sinus, and Oxia Palus quadrangles, Xanthe Terra hosts notable features like Ravi Vallis, Aromatum Chaos, and various craters. Imaged by Mars Express, Mars Global Surveyor, and Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, this area unveils ancient river valleys and deltas with thin layers, suggesting past precipitation on early Mars.
